import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib as mpl
import seaborn as sns

import plotly
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objs as go

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

source.39f75ad3:
changes_in_table = {'Sr. Data Analyst' : 'Senior Data Analyst', 
                    'Sr Data Analyst' : 'Senior Data Analyst',
                    'Data Analyst Junior' : 'Junior Data Analyst'}

df['Job Title'] = df['Job Title'].map(changes_in_table).fillna(df['Job Title'])
source.4aac5642:
fig = px.histogram(df_analyst, x='minimal_salary', marginal='box', 
                   color_discrete_sequence=['#330C73'])

fig.update_layout(
    
    height=600, width=800, title_text='Minimal Salary',
    
    xaxis_title='salaries', yaxis_title="count", title_x = 0.5,
    
    font=dict(
            family="Courier New, monospace",
            size=18,
            color="black"
        
))

fig.show()

source.39852b37:
fig = go.Figure()

fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=df_analyst['Job Title'].value_counts().head(20).index,
       y=df_analyst['Job Title'].value_counts().head(20).values,
       marker_color = '#330C73'))

fig.update_layout(
    
    height=600, width=800, title_text='Number of job openings by Job Titles',
    
    xaxis_title='job title', yaxis_title="count", title_x = 0.5,
    
    font=dict(
            family="Courier New, monospace",
            size=14,
            color="black"
        
))


fig.show()

source.0e34add3:
df_copy = df_analyst[['Job Title','python', 'sql','excel','tableau', 'power bi']].copy()
technology = df_copy.groupby('Job Title')[['python', 'sql','excel','tableau', 'power bi']].sum().sort_values(by='python', ascending=False).head(10)
df_technology = pd.DataFrame(technology)
df_technology.reset_index(inplace=True)
df_technology['number_of_job_openings'] = df_analyst['Job Title'].value_counts()[:10].values
df_technology
source.949a58e3:
fig = px.bar(df_technology, x='Job Title', y=['python', 'sql', 'excel', 'tableau',
                                             'power bi'],
            color_discrete_sequence=px.colors.qualitative.G10)

fig.update_layout(
    
    height=600, width=800, title_text='Number of job openings by Job Title with technologies',
    xaxis_title='job title', yaxis_title="count",
    legend_title='technologies',
    
    font=dict(
            family="Courier New, monospace",
            size=14,
            color="black"
        
))


fig.show()
source.0ff5da33:
fig = px.scatter(df_analyst, y='Company Name', x='minimal_salary', color = 'Rating',
                 color_continuous_scale=px.colors.sequential.Bluered_r)

fig.update_layout(
    
    height=600, width=800, title_text='Minimal salary and company names with rating scores',
    
    xaxis_title='salary', yaxis_title='Company Name', title_x = 0.5,
    
    font=dict(
            family="Courier New, monospace",
            size=12,
            color="black"
        
))

fig.show()

source.fcf23ec4:
There's one job title which is the most common and it's Data Analyst - there's 405 job openings for this role. Going further:

* Senior Data Analyst - 120
* Junior Data Analyst - 47
* Business Data Analyst - 28
source.30f9ceda: INCOMA and Kelly seems to be interesting offers with maximal salary 190K

**Observations**

* ratings have average 3.73 at round
* for minimal salary we can see that average is around 50K, for maximal we can see that there's around 90K, and average from minimal and maximal is around 70K
* We should expect some outilners based this observations

source.d912de89: As data inexorably growing faster and faster the data analysis jobs will need more and more employees, data science job as the "sexiest job od XXI century" sounds so tempting but as you can see - you can also work with data, earn a lot of money and you don't have to be a data scientist. I think that data analyst job with Excel, Power BI or SQL is the best place to start adventure with data science.
